Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Postoperative Sore Throat Prevention

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted in a hospital setting.

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults undergoing elective surgery requiring tracheal intubation.

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to receive either pharmacological interventions (NSAIDs or steroids), non-pharmacological interventions, or traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) therapy.

Objective.evidence: This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of various interventions in preventing POST.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of POST within 24 hours post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis included 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group, using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant reduction in POST incidence compared to the control group (mean difference = 15%, 95% CI 10% to 20%; p < 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, with 3% in the intervention group and 1% in the control group experiencing minor side effects.

Funding.evidence: Funding: Supported by hospital intramural sources.
